channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: Bold, beautiful, and… brainy? Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Offices are located within Dubai, Malta, and Malaysia so if you’re in one of those places, you’re one step closer to where you need to be. Hanging out in Honolulu? Not to worry. For the right person, they’ve got a work-sponsored visa and relocation package — if you’ve got the expertise and an adventurous spirit, they’ve got the will and means to get you where you need to be.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Report on Volunteerism in the Perl Community
Special Accounts
item.description: Interesting use of sets and not list. Very smart and unique. Well done.

item.title: Special Merge
item.description: Python is the choice of language this week for special bit characters. Perl fans shouldn't be disappointed as we have Perl in the discussion too.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #209
item.description: Nice use of state machine. I rarely see these days, so thank you for refresher.

item.title: An abc and @emails
item.description: Engaging task analysis that will keep you engrossed. You can even try the solution online. Cool.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 209
item.description: Master of Perl one-liner is out with his trick. Impressive result. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: grep and loop
item.description: Luca does with Raku what James does with Perl. Well done and thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 209: Special Bit Characters and Merge Account
item.description: Loved the discussion about the special bit characters task. Interesting aspects raised and explained. Thanks for the contributions.

item.title: PWC209 - Merge Account
item.description: A rather long solution from Flavio's own standard. Plenty to keep you busy.

item.title: PWC209 - Special Bit Characters
item.description: Use of regex made the solution so simple and easy to follow. Nice attempt.

item.title: ED-209: The Weekly Challenge
item.description: If you are looking for compact and powerful Perl solutions then this is the place. Well done, James.

item.title: Give A Little Bit
item.description: Use of CPAN can be very handy and get the job done smoothly. Very entertaining post, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Special Account
item.description: Such a detailed analysis, you wouldn't miss a thing. What a class post, as always. Keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 209
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Special Bit Characters" and "Merge Account" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 210
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Kill and Win" and "Number Collision". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Fixing code and documentation, setting up CI - Sending Pull-Requests
item.description: You might have heard about the Open Source Development Course I teach. During one of the most recent meetings we worked on a Perl module. You can also check the web site of the course and the GitHub repo where you can find the links to the video recordings.

item.title: Analyzing New York City Traffic Collisions with Perl One-Liners and Linux
Text::Extract::Word, MsOffice::Word::Surgeon - Weekly Travelling in CPAN
An Interesting Perl Pattern That Doesn't Work
item.description: A pattern that is supposed to use a closure to protect a configuration hash from being mutated by its callers. Unfortunately this pattern has a terrible flaw.

item.title: Command-line editing
item.description: And what about Ctrl-X Ctrl-E ?

item.title: Introducing Exporter::Almighty
item.description: Exporter::Almighty is a module designed to reduce boilerplate in your utils-like modules, and increase their functionality.

item.title: Community Input Requested - Future of TPRF website(s)
item.description: Where, if I am not mistaken, TPRF stands for The Perl and Raku Foundation

item.title: Now Accepting: TPRC Proposals for 2024
item.description: It's time to plan TPRC 2024. If you are interested in organizing the event in your city, please submit a proposal by April 28th. (Oh and I think TPRC stand for The Perl and Raku Conference.)

item.title: #609 - Open Source and your workplace
item.description:
Hi there!

You probably already heard about the Open Source Development Course I started to teach. The core assumption there is that helping more people contribute to Open Source will make the world a better place.

As part of that course I started to collect information on Open Source projects by governments, corporations, higher education institutions, and non profits. The results so far can be seen here.

However I have another direction with this I'd like to understand how your workplaces relate to open source. Do they have any formal guidelines on how you can contribute to open source? Informal ones? What happens if you encounter a bug in an open source project you use? Are you allowed to contribute the fix back? On company time? Do they have a budget to support open source contributors who are not employees of the company? e.g. random Jane who works on some open source project? Please get in touch with me if you can share anything.

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: editorial
